newsitem.title: ESTONIA: More cash, no crash for Estonian shares - analysts.
newsitem.headline: More cash, no crash for Estonian shares - analysts.

text.p: Although the rise of Estonian shares during July and August has been meteoric, prices may not yet have peaked and a stockmarket crash is seen as unlikely, dealers and analysts said on Friday.
At worst, a short-term correction may take place, they said.

Since the start of July the Talse Index has soared by around 50 percent. Since the start of the year, the Estonian bourse has jumped a massive 158 percent or 253.2 points to 413.20 at the close of trade Thursday.

Over the past five weeks, usually a slow period, leading bank Hansapank, which accounts for 40 percent of the market, has risen 84.9 kroons or 63 percent to 219.90 kroons while second-largest bank Hoiupank jumped 110 kroons or 75 percent to 256.
"The fundamentals from the companies' first-half results are very good and all the news out of Estonia is good," said Katri Kumpulainen, London-based analyst with Societe Generale.
Kumpulainen said the Talse bourse was a "liquidity-driven market" and thus subject to sharp price swings -- a view shared by James Oates, analyst at UBS in London.
"It is a small bourse so a small amount of money can move it a long way," said Oates.
There were rumours foreign investors were fuelling the boom in prices, but both local dealers and foreign analysts see the gains as locally driven.
"We are seeing foreign investors as the net sellers at present and it looks to be mostly local investment that is keeping the bourse up," a local senior trader said.
The most recent rise came on news the EU Commission recommended Estonia to start talks to join the European Union along with Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Slovenia.
"News that Estonia would be included in the first wave of EU expansion did have an effect and the local market viewed it very positively," said Nomura analyst Martin Gollner.
"It is good news for the medium term but local brokers seem to be bidding up the market on that news," he added.
Estonia has a strong local investor base with institutional and private investors placing more funds in equities.
But despite the sharp gains, investors appetite for Estonian shares does not appear to be dying out just yet and a correction, although likely, may not come for several more weeks.
"Prices are seen to be high but while the fundamentals of the companies remain good there is no expectation of a big downward correction," a senior dealer said.
In terms of price/earnings, Estonia at 15.2 is approaching Hungary at 15. Poland is rated at 11.6 while the Czech republic is at 10.8, analysts said.
But givens Hansapank's huge weighting in the Talse Index, comparisons with other bourses are difficult, Kumpulainen said.
With the approach of large privatisations in Latvia and Lithuania, interest is expected to focus on the neighbouring bourses, allowing Estonia to cool.
"I expect some interest in the markets of the other two Baltic countries especially with the privatisation of large companies under way," Nomura's Gollner said.
-- David Mardiste, Tallinn Newsroom +372 620 9202 reuters@reuters.ee
